section.title: The Curves of Trigonometry
section.p: As we have seen, when a point moves in a clockwise direction from \left(1,0 \right) around the unit circle, the y-coordinate moves continuously from 0 to 1 and back to 0, then to -1 and back to 0 again to start the process all over. In a similar manner, the x-coordinate begins at 1, moves smoothly to 0, to -1, to 0 again, and back to 1 to repeat the process. These repetitive motions repeat every 2\pi units and produce continuous curves that oscillate periodically between maximum and minimum values. Such curves are called sinusoids. Both the sine function and the cosine function are sinusoids.

The graph of the cosine function, y = \cos \left(x \right), is shown in . The graph is periodic with period 2\pi, and it oscillates between a maximum of 1 and a minimum of -1. The amplitude of a periodic graph is defined as half of the length of the range of values obtained in the graph and can be calculated as follows: \text{amplitude } = \frac{\text{maximum value}-\text{minimume value}}{2} Thus, the amplitude of y = \cos \left(x \right) is \frac{1 - \left(-1 \right)}{2}=1. The period and amplitude of the sine function, y = \sin \left(x \right), are the same as those of the cosine function.

The graph of y = \sin \left(x \right) can be obtained by shifting the graph of y = \cos \left(x \right) to the right \frac{\pi}{2} units; this results in the shifted graph passing through the origin and having a maximum at x = \frac{\pi}{2}. Similarly, we see that the graph of y = \cos \left(x \right) can be obtained by shifting the graph of y = \sin \left(x \right) to the left \frac{\pi}{2}. This gives us two important representations that allow us to change from sine to cosine or from cosine to sine easily. We can express this co-function relationship algebraically: \cos \left(x \right) = \sin \left(x + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) and \sin \left(x \right) = \cos \left(x - \frac{\pi}{2} \right).
Note that the graph of y = \cos \left(x \right) is symmetric about the y-axis and therefore is an even function. This tells us that \cos \left(x \right) = \cos \left(-x \right) for any x.

For the graph of y = \sin \left(x \right), if we reflect the graph only for x \lt 0 about the y-axis, we create a graph that is symmetric about the x-axis. Another way to view this is that the sine function is symmetric about the origin, making it an odd function. This means that \sin \left(-x \right) = -\sin \left(x \right) for any x.

In , the x-intercepts of y = \cos \left(x \right) occur at -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}, and \frac{3\pi}{2}, or, in general, at odd multiples of \frac{\pi}{2}. These x-coordinates can be written as \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi or \frac{\left(2k + 1 \right)\pi}{2}, in which k is any integer. The maximum values of the function occur at even multiples of \pi, and the minimum values occur at odd multiples of \pi.
Since the sine and cosine functions are important families of functions in mathematics, we include them in our “toolkit” of functions.

statement.p: Use the periodicity of the sine and cosine functions to evaluate \cos \left(7\pi \right) and \sin \left(\frac{17\pi}{2} \right).

solution.p: The fact that the period of the cosine function is 2\pi means that \cos \left(b + 2\pi \right) = \cos \left(b \right) for any real number b. In other words, the y-coordinate on the graph of f\left(x \right) = \cos \left(x \right) at x = b + 2\pi is the same as the y-coordinate at x = b. This is illustrated in .

The key to evaluating \cos \left(7\pi \right) is recognizing that the behavior of the graph of f\left(x \right) = \cos \left(x \right) on the interval 0 \le x \le 2\pi is repeated on the intervals 2\pi \le x \le 4\pi, 4\pi \le x \le 6\pi, and so forth. Between x = 0 and x = 6\pi the cosine graph completes three cycles, and x = 7\pi falls within the fourth cycle of the graph (see ).

The behavior of f\left(x \right) = \cos \left(x \right) from 6\pi to 8\pi is the same as the behavior from 0 to 2\pi, so: \cos \left(7\pi \right) = \cos \left(6\pi + \pi \right) = \cos \left(\pi \right) = -1.

Since the period of the sine function is also 2\pi, \sin \left(b + 2\pi \right) = \sin \left(b \right) is true for all real numbers b. It is also true that the behavior of the graph of f\left(x \right) = \sin \left(x \right) on the interval 0 \le x \le 2\pi is repeated on the intervals 2\pi \le x \le 4\pi, 4\pi \le x \le 6\pi, and so on. Between x = 0 and x = 8\pi, the sine graph completes four cycles, and x = \frac{17\pi}{2} falls within the fifth cycle of the graph (see ).

Since the behavior of f\left(x \right) = \sin \left(x \right) from 8\pi to 10\pi is the same as the behavior from 0 to 2\pi, we know that \sin \left(\frac{17\pi}{2} \right) = \sin \left(8\pi + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2} \right) = 1

statement.p: Find all solutions of the inequality \cos \left(x \right) \lt 0.

solution.p: The graph of the function y = \cos \left(x \right) in shows intervals where the cosine function has negative values; these intervals occur between the zeros of the function. The zeros of y = \cos \left(x \right) occur at x = \frac{\pi}{2} + k\pi, in which k is any integer. One interval where the values of \cos \left(x \right) are negative is \left(\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3\pi}{2} \right).

Since the cosine function has a period of 2\pi, values of \cos \left(x \right) will be negative for any x that satisfies \frac{\pi}{2} + 2k\pi \lt x \lt \frac{3\pi}{2} + 2k\pi, in which k is an integer. Substituting an integer value for k into the inequality \frac{\pi}{2} + 2k\pi \lt x \lt \frac{3\pi}{2} + 2k\pi produces a particular interval where \cos \left(x \right) \lt 0. For example, if k = 0, the interval is \frac{\pi}{2} \lt x \lt \frac{3\pi}{2}. If k = 1, the interval is \frac{5\pi}{2} \lt x \lt \frac{7\pi}{2}. If k = -1, the interval is -\frac{3\pi}{2} \lt x \lt -\frac{\pi}{2}. Use a graph to verify that these intervals correspond to regions where \cos \left(x \right) has negative values.

subsection.title: The Graph of the Tangent Function
subsection.p: Recall from our work earlier in this chapter that \tan \left(\theta \right) = \frac{\sin \left(\theta \right)}{\cos \left(\theta \right)}. We can use this identity, \tan \left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)}, to graph y = \tan \left(x \right). Many important mathematical ideas are based on the quotient of \sin x and \cos x. We will use a table of values so that we can investigate the graph of the tangent function h\left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} on the interval 0 \le x \le 2\pi. The table in shows values of \sin \left(x \right), \cos \left(x \right), and \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} from x = 0 to x = \frac{\pi}{2}.

figure.caption: Values of \cos \left(x \right), \cos \left(x \right) and \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} from x = 0 to x = \frac{\pi}{2}

subsection.p: Since values of \sin x and \cos x are both non-negative between x = 0 to x = \frac{\pi}{2}, the ratio \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} is also non-negative for all x-values in this interval. The table shows that the values of \sin x increase from 0 to 1 and that the values of \cos x decrease from 1 to 0. The table also shows that the ratio \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} is zero when x = 0, and the ratio increases as x increases. When x = \frac{\pi}{2}, the function will be undefined, since \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2} \right) = 0, and division by zero is undefined. However, as x- approaches \frac{\pi}{2} from the left, the values of h\left(x \right) approach infinity. For example, \frac{\sin \left(\frac{11\pi}{24} \right)}{\cos \left(\frac{11\pi}{24} \right)} \approx 7.59575 and \frac{\sin \left(\frac{23\pi}{48} \right)}{\cos \left(\frac{23\pi}{48} \right)} \approx 15.25705. This occurs because values of \sin x in the numerator approach 1 while values of \cos x in the denominator approach 0. A denominator that is approaching zero with a numerator approaching one causes the ratio \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} to increase without bound.

To further investigate the tangent function h\left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} on the interval 0 \le x \le 2\pi, let us study the table of values for \sin x, \cos x, and \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} from x = \frac{\pi}{2} to x = \pi in .

figure.caption: Values of \cos \left(x \right), \cos \left(x \right) and \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} from x = 0 to x = \pi

subsection.p: On the interval from x = \frac{\pi}{2} to x = \pi, values of \sin x are non-negative, and values of \cos x are non-positive, so the ratio \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} is non-positive on this interval. The table shows that the values of \sin x decrease from 1 to 0, and the values of \cos x decrease from 0 to -1. The table also shows that the ratio \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} is negative when x is near \frac{\pi}{2}, and the ratio increases towards zero as x increases.

So, what have we discovered about \tan \left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)}?
The sign (positive or negative) of h\left(x \right) = \tan \left(x \right) is determined by the signs of \sin x and \cos x.
Any x-value that makes \sin x equal zero also makes the value of h\left(x \right) equal zero.
Any x-value that makes \cos x equal zero is not in the domain of h\left(x \right) because division by zero is undefined.
Evaluating h\left(x \right) at x- values near the zeros of \cos x indicates that h\left(x \right) has vertical asymptotes at these x-values.
The graph of h\left(x \right) = \tan \left(x \right) on the interval 0 \le x \le \pi is shown in .

figure.caption: Graph of \tan \left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} on the interval -\pi \le x \le \pi
Values of \cos \left(x \right), \cos \left(x \right) and \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} from x = \pi to x = \frac{3\pi}{2}

subsection.p: shows values of \sin x, \cos x, and \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} from x = \pi to x = \frac{3\pi}{2}. On this interval, values of \sin x are non-positive, values of \cos x are non-positive, and values of \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} are non-negative or undefined. In comparing the values of \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} on the interval \pi \le x \le \frac{3\pi}{2} with the values of \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} on the interval 0 \le x \le \frac{\pi}{2}, we find that, although the values of \sin x and \cos x differ on these two intervals, the values of their ratio are identical. We can make a table of values of \sin x, \cos x, and \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} from x = \frac{3\pi}{2} to x = 2\pi to confirm that the behavior of h\left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} on \frac{3\pi}{2} \le x \le 2\pi is identical to the behavior of h\left(x \right) on \frac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \pi.

The repetition of values of h\left(x \right) = \tan \left(x \right) = \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} indicates that the tangent function is periodic. The period of h\left(x \right) = \tan \left(x \right) is \pi because h\left(\pi + x \right) = h\left(x \right) for all values of x. The fact that h\left(x \right) = \tan \left(x \right) has the period of \pi can be investigated using the graph shown in . Values of \sin x for 0 \le x \le \pi are the opposite of values of \sin x for 0 \le x \le \pi. Similarly, values of \cos x for 0 \le x \le \pi are the opposite of values of \cos x for \pi \le x \le 2\pi. Therefore, the values of \frac{\sin \left(x \right)}{\cos \left(x \right)} = \tan \left(x \right) for 0 \le x \le \pi repeat for \pi \le x \le 2\pi, since both parts of the ratio are opposites.

subsection.p: Based on information about zeros, asymptotes, and periodicity, the graph of h\left(x \right) = \tan \left(x \right) on the interval 0 \le x \le 2\piis shown in .

We can use knowledge of symmetries and periodicity to graph y = \tan x on a larger domain than is shown in . We first determine the symmetry of \tan xby simplifying \tan \left(-x \right). Recall that a function f\left(x \right) is odd if f\left(-x \right) = f\left(x \right) for all x-values. Similarly, a function f\left(x \right) is even if f\left(-x \right) = f\left(x \right) for all x-values.
